benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/customFields - Add custom fields to account

covered: POST/Valid Payload: Multiple success scenarios return 201 with JSON array body; required (X-Killbill-CreatedBy) and optional (Reason, Comment) headers covered.

POST/Invalid Payload: Malformed JSON, empty body/empty array, missing required header, invalid data types, missing required fields, unsupported fields, duplicate field names, and null values are exercised with 400 responses.
Path parameter validation: Invalid UUID format for accountId returns 400.
Large payload handling: Maximum payload accepted; oversized payload rejected.
Server/dependency failures: Service unavailable and dependent inconsistency scenarios included.
Security validation: SQL injection and XSS payloads rejected.
Performance and concurrency: Response time under normal load; concurrent requests with no corruption; resilience via retry after transient network failure.
Query parameters: Unexpected query parameter tolerated without breaking creation.
Association check: Created custom fields asserted to be associated with the specified account.
gaps: Duplicate submission/idempotency: No scenario to resend the same payload and verify no duplicate custom fields are created (idempotency or dedup behavior).
Batch atomicity: No test for mixed valid/invalid items in the same array to verify all-or-nothing transaction semantics.
Server error handling (500): No explicit database failure/internal error path returning 500.
Resource existence status: Non-existent account uses 400; should clarify and test 404 Not Found if that is the intended behavior.
Content negotiation: No test for missing/wrong Content-Type leading to 415 Unsupported Media Type, or unacceptable Accept header (406) if enforced.
Response headers: Produces application/json not asserted via Content-Type header; no checks for other expected headers.
Authorization (403): No scenario for authenticated user lacking permission.
Rate limiting/throttling: No scenario for 429 Too Many Requests under burst load.
Top-level schema type: No test sending an object instead of the required JSON array.
Retry idempotency: TC20 does not assert that retry created fields only once (no duplicates after transient failure).
Persistence verification: No follow-up GET to confirm fields were actually persisted post-201.
Spec alignment: TC05 expects response to include previously existing fields; story states response represents the created custom fields only—this is inconsistent and should be corrected.
recommendations: Add a duplicate submission test: send the same request twice (with/without an Idempotency-Key if supported) and verify no duplicate custom fields are created.
Add a batch atomicity test: include one invalid CustomField among valid ones; expect the entire request to fail and no fields to be created.
Introduce server error handling tests: simulate DB failure to assert 500 response and safe rollback.
Clarify and align status for non-existent account (prefer 404 Not Found); update TC10 accordingly and assert no side effects.
Add content negotiation tests: wrong/missing Content-Type -> 415; optionally test 406 for unsupported Accept.
Assert response headers: verify Content-Type: application/json on 201/400 per Produces, and any auditing-related effects if applicable.
Add a 403 Forbidden test for insufficient permissions (authenticated but unauthorized).
Add a rate limiting test to validate 429 behavior under bursts.
Add schema shape test: send a single CustomField object instead of an array and expect a 400/422.
Enhance TC20: assert that only one set of fields exists after retry (no duplicates), possibly using a GET to validate.
Add a post-creation persistence check: after 201, GET the account’s custom fields and verify presence/values.
Correct TC05 to expect only the newly created fields in the response (per story), while separately verifying that previously existing fields remain unchanged via a GET.
Optionally add i18n tests for unicode/emoji in names/values to validate encoding and length constraints.
